threats.title: Unauthorized access via stolen credentials
threats.description: An attacker could log in as a legitimate user by stealing or guessing credentials.
threats.mitigation: Enforce strong password policies, MFA, account lockouts.

threats.title: Overloading server with requests
threats.description: Excessive traffic could crash the web server, making services unavailable.
threats.mitigation: Rate limiting, firewalls, load balancers, DoS protection services.

threats.title: SQL Injection on Customer Database
threats.description: An attacker can inject malicious SQL via user-controllable inputs (forms, query parameters, headers) to read, modify, or delete sensitive data in the Customer database, or escalate privileges by modifying backend logic. Common vectors include unparameterized SQL queries, concatenation of user input into queries, and insufficient input validation.
threats.mitigation:
Use parameterized queries / prepared statements for all database access.
Use ORM methods that avoid raw SQL when possible.
Validate and sanitize input on server side (whitelist approach).

threats.title: Broken Object-Level Authorization (BOLA)
threats.description: Attacker manipulates object identifiers or tokens to access/modify other users' resources.
threats.mitigation: Server-side per-object checks; validate and verify tokens; enforce roles/scopes; unit/integration tests.

threats.title: Excessive Data Exposure
threats.description: API returns more fields than needed, leaking sensitive info.
threats.mitigation: Output filtering; DTOs/schemas; least-privilege responses; API contract validation.

threats.title: Denial of Service
threats.description: High request volume or abuse causes degraded or unavailable API service.
threats.mitigation: Rate limits, throttling, autoscaling, WAF, circuit breakers and alerts.

threats.title: Broken Authentication
threats.description: The microservice relies on weak or improperly validated tokens/credentials, allowing attackers to impersonate users.
threats.mitigation: Validate signed tokens; use short-lived tokens; token revocation; enforce MFA where needed.

threats.title: Insufficient Authorization (Missing RBAC)
threats.description: Missing role- or scope-based authorization checks allow access to unauthorized resources.
threats.mitigation: Implement RBAC/ABAC server-side; verify permissions on each request; use automated tests.

threats.title: Insecure Inter-Service Communication
threats.description: Unencrypted or unauthenticated communication between microservices allows interception or manipulation.
threats.mitigation: Use TLS/mTLS, service mesh, or API gateway with authentication and encryption.

threats.title: Unauthorized Admin Access
threats.description: Attackers gain administrative access to management servers via weak or stolen credentials.
threats.mitigation: Enforce strong passwords, MFA, session timeouts, and monitor login attempts.

threats.title: Insecure Remote Management Protocols
threats.description: Use of unencrypted or poorly secured remote protocols (e.g., RDP, SSH, Telnet) exposes credentials or data.
threats.mitigation: Use encrypted protocols (SSH with keys, TLS), disable insecure services, limit access via VPN/firewall.

threats.title: Exploitation of Unpatched Software
threats.description: Vulnerabilities in OS, management software, or agents could be exploited for unauthorized access or control.
threats.mitigation: Apply regular patches, monitor CVEs, and automate updates where possible.

threats.title: SQL Injection
threats.description: Untrusted input could be injected into queries, exposing or modifying database data.
threats.mitigation: Use parameterized queries/ORMs and validate input using whitelist patterns.

threats.title: Excessive DB Privileges
threats.description: DB Controller runs with overly privileged accounts, increasing attack impact.
threats.mitigation: Apply least-privilege principles and separate roles for DB accounts.

threats.title: Unauthenticated Endpoint Access
threats.description: Endpoints exposed without authentication can be accessed by attackers.
threats.mitigation: Mitigation or prevention such as providing backoff, resource management and avoiding forced deadlock

threats.title: SQL Injection
threats.description: Unsanitized input from applications can allow attackers to execute arbitrary SQL commands.
threats.mitigation: Use parameterized queries, ORM frameworks, and input validation to prevent injection.

threats.title: Weak or Default Database Credentials
threats.description: Default or weak passwords allow attackers to easily gain access to the database.
threats.mitigation: Enforce strong password policies and disable default accounts.

threats.title: Lack of Backup or Recovery Testing
threats.description: Database may be unrecoverable after failure due to missing or untested backups.
threats.mitigation: Implement regular automated backups and perform periodic restoration tests.

threats.title: Unencrypted Backup Data
threats.description: Backup data stored locally without encryption can be accessed if physical or system compromise occurs.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt all backups at rest and in transit; use strong encryption keys and secure storage.

threats.title: Backup Media Theft or Loss
threats.description: Physical backup drives or media can be stolen or lost, exposing sensitive data.
threats.mitigation: Store backups in secure, access-controlled environments; maintain inventory logs; encrypt portable media.

threats.title: Unauthorized Access to Backup Files
threats.description: Lack of proper access control allows unauthorized users to view or modify backups.
threats.mitigation: Apply least-privilege permissions; enforce role-based access; monitor file access logs.

threats.title: Weak API Authentication
threats.description: The system may accept requests without properly validating banking API credentials, allowing impersonation.
threats.mitigation: Use strong token-based authentication (e.g., OAuth2, mTLS) and verify tokens on every request.

threats.title: Lack of Non-Repudiation for Banking Requests
threats.description: The banking system could later deny sending specific API calls or transaction confirmations.
threats.mitigation: Require signed requests and maintain tamper-proof logs with timestamps.

threats.title: Exposed API Keys Allow Bank Spoofing
threats.description: If API keys or certificates are leaked, attackers could impersonate the bank system.
threats.mitigation: Store API keys securely in a vault and rotate them periodically.

threats.title: Man-in-the-Middle attack
threats.description: An attacker intercepts and modifies sensitive financial data exchanged between the bank system and internal servers.
threats.mitigation: Use mutual TLS authentication and certificate pinning.

threats.title: Data exposure over unsecured API
threats.description: Sensitive banking information is sent in plaintext or with weak encryption.
threats.mitigation: Enforce HTTPS/TLS 1.3 and encrypt sensitive payloads.

threats.title: Replay attack on financial transactions
threats.description: An attacker captures and resends valid banking transactions to manipulate account balances or duplicate operations.
threats.mitigation: Implement nonce or timestamp validation on each request.

threats.title: User identity spoofing
threats.description: An attacker may impersonate a legitimate user to gain unauthorized access to the system.
threats.mitigation: Implement strong authentication (MFA) and session validation.

threats.title: Stolen credentials reused
threats.description: Credentials leaked in previous breaches could be reused to impersonate a valid user.
threats.mitigation: Enforce password rotation and monitor for breached credentials.

threats.title: Session hijacking
threats.description: Attackers may hijack an active user session to act as the user without credentials.
threats.mitigation: Use secure cookies, enable HTTPS, and set short session lifetimes.
